awd_titl_txt: Novel phases of quantum matter in numerical simulations, field theory and materials
awd_abstract_narration:
NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY

This award supports theoretical and computational research and education aimed at improving our understanding of the collective motion of an infinite sea of electrons when they are cooled close to the absolute zero of temperature. The complexity of this "quantum many-body problem" arises both because there is a large number of electrons that influence each other and also because at such low temperatures the unfamiliar to everyday experience laws of quantum mechanics become operative. Our understanding of theories to describe the physical phenomena involved finds important applications in describing the properties of a wide range of materials.

The range of phenomena that quantum many-body systems can display is wide and more are being constantly discovered. Small changes in the conditions of the electrons can produce dramatic changes in their behavior. An important class of phenomena where this is evident is found in quantum magnetism, which encompasses the study of patterns of internal magnetic fields that develop spontaneously in materials. In the last century, advances in experimental techniques have resulted in the discovery of hundreds of materials with unusual magnetic behavior. Linking the measured magnetic behavior to the nature of the atoms that form the materials is an important challenge, both for our fundamental understanding of nature and for potential applications of novel magnets in technology.  Computer simulations have emerged as a powerful tool to solve such problems. A major component of this project will be the development and application of novel computer algorithms to tackle unsolved problems in quantum magnetism.

In addition to research, the project will contribute to the training and education of undergraduate and graduate students in the fields of condensed matter physics and advanced computational methods, opening up a broad spectrum of career opportunities for them after graduation. The PI will also reach outside the University of Kentucky, by visiting various liberal arts colleges in the state of Kentucky (including Centre College and Berea College), giving popular-level lectures on quantum physics and leading discussions with students on future opportunities in graduate school. Summer research opportunities will also be offered to students at neighboring liberal arts colleges. The PI will work to forge collaborations and connections between the nuclear and particle theory community and the condensed matter community though the organization of conferences and symposia at national and international venues.

TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This award supports theoretical and computational research and education in the field of strongly correlated quantum condensed matter physics, combining large-scale numerical simulations and field theoretic studies. The numerical research will involve both the development of new algorithms to study strongly correlated systems as well as their application to a number of problems of interest. Some of the major topics to be studied include:

(1) spin-liquid phases in non-bipartite quantum spin models,
(2) quantum-spin-ice-like emergent electrodynamics in spin models,
(3) quantum criticality in spin systems with disorder,
(4) simulations of lattice fermion models with quadratic band touching in two and three dimensions with applications to bilayer graphene and the pyrochlore iridates,
(5) the effect of interactions on Dirac fermions in two and three dimensions, with applications to various strongly correlated systems,
(6) deconfined criticality of two-dimensional spin models,
(7) improvement of our understanding of the "sign problem" of QMC and broadening the class of sign-problem-free models.

The overarching theme is to identify new phenomena that essentially involve strong electron-electron interactions and which cannot be analyzed by perturbative methods. 

In addition to research, the project will contribute to the training and education of undergraduate and graduate students in the fields of condensed matter physics and advanced computational methods, opening up a broad spectrum of career opportunities for them after graduation. The PI will also reach outside the University of Kentucky, by visiting various liberal arts colleges in the state of Kentucky (including Centre College and Berea College), giving popular-level lectures on quantum physics and leading discussions with students on future opportunities in graduate school. Summer research opportunities will also be offered to students at neighboring liberal arts colleges. The PI will work to forge collaborations and connections between the nuclear and particle theory community and the condensed matter community though the organization of conferences and symposia at national and international venues.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF award has supported the research group of a faculty member at the University of Kentucky that studies quantum physics of many particles. There are two aspects of the quantum many body problem that were studied with the support of this award. In the first theme, the PI and his group studied models of quantum physics using sophisticated numerical algorithms. A special emphasis was placed on quantum spin models with higher spin quantum numbers that display unusual behaviors absent in the simple S=1/2 models that have been intensely studied in the past. In this work the PI's group developed a new algorithmic strategy to find new models that can be simulated on a computer and discovered a model that hosts an exiotic phase transition. The second theme was the study of the manifestations of quantum many body physics in real quantum materials. The primary quantum materials studied in this award was graphene, the two-dimensional lattice network of Carbon atoms and Cobalt based quantum magnets. The graphene system was studied in a regime of high magnetic field where it displays unusal quantum Hall effects that are being actively studied by various experimental groups. In another work, surprisingly simple models of spins were shown to capture the Cobalt based magnets studied both with neutron scattering and THz spectroscopy. This study also showed that these THz experiments were the first to provide a physical realization of the Kramers-Wannier duality, a foundational result on the statisttical mechanics of the Ising model. Some of the collaborations that were started through the work supported by this award will lead to long term joint work between the members of the PI’s group and leading scientists around the globe. The PI and his group have disseminated his research results in 13 publications in leading journals of the field including Physical Review Letters and Nature Physics. The PI has delivered presentations at 12 international conferences, and over 10 seminars and colloquia at research institutions in the US and Europe. 

Outside of the scientific results produced, the largest broader impact from this award is the mentoring of five graduate students, two of whom are still working on their PhD, the other three have gone onto postdoctoral positions. The PI’s group has also given undergraduate researchers the opportunity to get a feeling for advanced theoretical physics and learn ideas not covered in the standard undergraduate syllabus by participating in research projects often in collaboration with graduate students. Other activities undertaken by the PI have been public lectures at neighboring four year colleges in Kentucky, like Center College and Morehead State University, and a science presentation at a local Lexington brewery.  The PI has also given a number of graduate training courses on advanced topic at institutions around the world including, Harish Chandra Institute and Indian Institute of Technology Bombay and the University of Tokyo.
